prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Redshift group A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup ok for continuum, and for possible bonus lines for z=1.3142-1.3228 and z=1.3965-1.4059

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As described in the scientific justification, we can use extrapolation from the measured average Herschel flux to expect on average an integrated 850um continuum of 1.2mJy for a source. An RMS of 0.04mJy per 0.2" beam then allows us to map sources similar to or brighter than this average integrated continuum. We can also still detect total emission from individual sources fainter than this average, or put very strong limits on nondetections. We hence do not make an attempt to anticipate the flux of a given source, and use this RMS 0.04mJy and a nominal 'peak flux density per beam' of 0.5mJy throughout. While sources may vary around that peak flux density depending on total flux and structure, the peak will always be faint <few mJy, and does not raise dynamic range questions.
This is a continuum driven project, but because of the potential to detect CO(7-6) (and for high SFR CI(2-1)) we have used the 'spectral line' type to emulate the 'single continuum' type with the sole modification of removing the small gap between basebands (as recommended in helpdesk ticket #4538). This allows to reduce overheads by using the same setup for a group of sources with similar redshift, and still ensure that any expected line is at least 0.65GHz away from the edges of one of these combined basebands. The 31MHz resolution is fine for extragalactic line work. We have done the necessary observed-rest calculations externally and express the observations in observed frequencies and a virtual z=0. To reflect the continuum driven nature of the project, we refer the RMS to a 'line' over the full aggregate bandwidth of the four basebands, which gives results as in 'single continuum'.

As described in more detail above, we use a 'line' setup that allows detection of both continuum and additional lines for sources within the specified redshift windows. To reflect the mainly continuum driven nature project we specify for sensitivity purposes a 'line' width corresponding to the total continuum bandwidth. The correlator setup and 31MHz resolution is however also well matched to lines of typical extragalactic width.
Resolution 0.2" is chosen to resolve down to physical 1.7kpc and still keep good sensitivity for extended emission. Largest angular scale 2" is appropriate for these distant galaxies.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Luminous L(2-10keV)>1E44 AGN at z>~1 are close to the redshift and AGN luminosity dominating accretion, and at the decisive point when cosmic accretion and star formation begin to decrease dramatically. Unlike lower luminosity AGN at similar redshift which are typically hosted by star forming main-sequence disks, little is known about their host properties and the mechanisms driving their evolution. We propose spatially resolved continuum observations of an unbiased sample of 20 such AGN in COSMOS, in order to quantify their star forming activity and shed light on the disk or merger nature of the hosts. We (1) individually identify heavily star forming and passive hosts, (2) determine whether the spatial extent of star formation suggests large disks or compact mergers and (3) put strong constraints on the long wavelength emission heated by the AGN proper, essential for the interpretation of spatially unresolved Herschel and ALMA studies of high-z AGN hosts. In addition, we will for the first time characterize the strength of CO(7-6) emission in a clean AGN sample, and obtain cold ISM kinematics via CI(2-1) in the highest SFR sources of the sample.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: There is an executed cycle 0 spatially unresolved continuum proposal in COSMOS (2011.0.0097.S Scoville) which was however -not- targeting X-ray sources. A cycle 2 project (2013.1.00884.S Alexander) is aiming at unresolved continuum of higher z AGN in COSMOS.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
